title: Nora's Methodology
shortDescription: Learn the science behind Nora's approach and start your first daily practice: Special Play Time.
objectives: Understand the science behind Nora's approach
Learn why connection comes before discipline
Start your first daily practice: Special Play Time

LessonSegment.bodyText:
Welcome to Day 1! Today, we are laying the foundation for a happier home. You will learn:

The science behind **Nora's approach**.

Why **connection** must come before **discipline**.

Your first daily practice: **Special Play Time**.

Nora blends decades of research from **Play Therapy**, **Triple P (Positive Parenting)**, and **Behavior Management**.

**Our Goal:** To make parenting easier by building a strong connection first.

**The Result:** This makes the discipline phase that comes later much smoother and more effective.

**Phase 1: Connect.**

Kids need to feel seen and safe before they listen. We build this through daily **Special Play Time**.

**Phase 2: Discipline.**

Once the relationship is steady, we introduce calm instructions and boundaries.

**Remember:** Connection drives cooperation.

Meet **Special Play Time**.

Think of this as your child's **"emotional gym."** It is a small daily dose of positive attention that builds trust.

**The Commitment:** Just 5 minutes a day.

**The Key:** Consistency is more powerful than duration.

**Time:** 5 minutes daily.

**Child Leads:** Your child is the "boss." You follow alongâ€”no questioning, commands, or criticizing.

**Right Toys:** Use imaginative toys (blocks, dolls, Play-Doh). Avoid rule-based games (board games) or solitary items (books, puzzles) that make you lead.
"It's time for our **Special Play Time**! For the next 5 minutes, you get to be the boss. You can choose any of these toys for us to play with."

Five minutes of practicing the **PEN skills** can feel exhausting, but this therapeutic dose is highly effective for improving your relationship.

You can choose to continue playing after five minutes, but you are still going to tell your child that **Special Time is over**.

Ending it officially releases you from the pressure to use PEN skills at the high intensity of Special Time.

ðŸ’¡ **Tip:** Continuing to sprinkle in positive skills throughout the rest of the day is highly encouraged because that is where even more change can happen!

If your child struggles with the end of the session, use countdowns to manage expectations:

â€¢ "Special Time ends in 3 minutes."
â€¢ "2 minutes..."
â€¢ "1 minute..."

This prepares them for the transition and reduces friction.
"Special Time is now over. I wanted to tell you that I really liked how you [insert specific praise about their behavior]."

Quiz.question: Why does Nora start with the Connect phase before teaching discipline?
Quiz.explanation: In early childhood, relationship drives cooperation.

QuizOption.optionText: Because kids only behave well when they're happy.
Because a strong parentâ€“child connection builds trust, making kids willing to listen.
Because playtime is more fun than rules.
Because young children don't understand boundaries.

title: The 3 Core Skills
shortDescription: Master the 3 core skills (Praise, Echo, Narrate) that make Special Play Time powerful and effective.
objectives: Learn the PEN skills (Praise, Echo, Narrate)
Understand how each skill builds connection
Practice using PEN skills during Special Play Time

LessonSegment.bodyText:
Now that you know how **Special Play Time** works, today we learn the skills that make it powerful.

These skills help your child feel understood, confident, and connected. When kids feel these things, they listen better all day long.

The 3 Core Skills are **Praise**, **Echo**, and **Narrate** (**PEN**).

They are adapted from evidence-based research but rewritten to be simple for real parents. Think of them as the "ingredients" that make Special Play Time effective.

These skills strengthen:
â€¢ **Connection** (your child feels seen and valued)
â€¢ **Attention** (your child stays focused longer)
â€¢ **Cooperation** (children follow instructions more easily later)

**Tell your child exactly what they are doing well.** Specific praise builds confidence and increases positive behavior.

**Example:** "I love how gently you are playing with the blocks!"

**Example:** "Great job sharing!"

**Why:** Builds confidence, increases positive behavior

ðŸ’¡ **Tip:** Praise the **specific action**, not the child's personality.

**Repeat or reflect what your child says.** It shows you are listening and builds language skills.

ðŸ‘¶ **Child:** "The car is fast!"
ðŸ‘¤ **You:** "The car is fast!"

**Why:** It makes your child feel heardâ€”and kids who feel heard cooperate more.

ðŸ’¡ **Tip:** Repeat or reflect what your child says.

**Describe what your child is doing, like a sports commentator.**

**Example:** "You're stacking the blue block on the red one."

**Why:** It keeps your child calm, focused, and engaged. It works even if they aren't talking much yet.

ðŸ’¡ **Tip:** Narration works even if your child isn't talking much yet.

Try mixing them today:

ðŸ‘¤ "You're lining up the cars." **(Narrate)**

ðŸ‘¶ **Child:** "This one is fastest!"
ðŸ‘¤ **You:** "The fastest one!" **(Echo)**

ðŸ‘¤ "I love how focused you are." **(Praise)**

Just be warm and follow their lead.

Quiz.question: What is the main purpose of the "Echo" skill?
Quiz.explanation: Echoing makes your child feel heardâ€”and builds trust.

QuizOption.optionText: To correct what your child says.
To show your child you're listening and build trust.

title: What NOT to Do
shortDescription: Learn the 3 habits to avoid during Special Play Time to keep your child in the lead.
objectives: Understand what to avoid during Special Play Time
Learn why commands, questions, and criticism disrupt connection

LessonSegment.bodyText:
To let connection grow, we must avoid 3 common habits during **Special Play Time**:

â€¢ **No Commands**
â€¢ **No Questions**
â€¢ **No Criticism**

These aren't "bad," but they pull your child out of the lead.

**Rule:** Don't tell your child what to do.

**Why:** Commands shift control back to you. When kids feel controlled, their creativity shrinks.

**Instead of:** "Put the blue block here."

**Try:** "I see you chose the green block!"

**Rule:** Avoid asking "What's that?" or "Why?"

**Why:** Questions feel like little tests. They interrupt your child's flow and make them focus on answering you rather than playing.

**Instead of:** "What are you drawing?"

**Try:** "You're drawing lots of circles!"

**Rule:** No pointing out mistakes or teaching.

**Why:** Even gentle corrections make a child feel judged. Special Play Time is for relationship-building, not skill-building.

**Instead of:** "That's not how you hold it."

**Try:** "You're holding it your own way."

Quiz.question: Why do we avoid questions during Special Play Time?
Quiz.explanation: Questions interrupt your child's flow and make them feel like they're being tested.

QuizOption.optionText: They interrupt your child's lead and feel like little tests.
Questions are confusing for young children.

title: Special Time as a Gym
shortDescription: Understand why Special Time feels like an intense "mental gym" workout rather than normal play.

LessonSegment.bodyText:
You might think, "I would never talk like this normally!" That is okay.

Think of Special Time as a **Mental Gym**.

It isn't meant to be spontaneous reality; it is a high-intensity workout for your parenting skills.

In the gym, you isolate muscles to strengthen them.

In Special Time, you isolate positive skills (**PEN**) and use them at high density (10-15 times per minute) while completely avoiding "Don't" skills.

This builds muscle memory.

We use this artificial intensity to overwrite old habits like nagging or correcting.

The goal isn't to be a commentator all day, but to practice enough that you naturally sprinkle these positive skills into your daily life later.

Practice the transition to show that connection continues even when the "gym session" ends.

**Script:** "Wow, Special Time is over! I loved how creative you were.

Now let's go make lunch." (Return to normal communication).

Quiz.question: Why does Special Time often feel unnatural or "fake" to parents initially?
Quiz.explanation: Special Time is an intentional "workout" to build skill density and muscle memory, not a reflection of casual conversation.

QuizOption.optionText: Because the child is not being spontaneous.
Because it is designed to be an intense, isolated skill-building practice that doesn't reflect spontaneous daily life.
Because the 5-minute time limit is too short.
Because the parent is using too many "Don't" skills.

title: Handling Whining (Selective Ignoring)
shortDescription: Learn to use Selective Ignoring to handle minor attention-seeking behaviors like whining during play.

LessonSegment.bodyText:
Sometimes kids test boundaries during Special Time with whining or pouting.

To handle this, we use **Selective Ignoring**.

This is the only tool for minor, attention-seeking misbehaviors during this time.

Immediately withdraw all attention.

No eye contact, no words, no physical touch.

Turn your body slightly away.

Focus on a spot on the wall.

You are ignoring the behavior, not the child.

The moment the whining stops (even for a second), you must immediately return attention with a Labeled **Praise**.

**Example:** Child stops whining.

ðŸ‘¤ **You:** "Thank you for using your quiet hands/voice!" This reinforces that calm behavior gets your love.

Quiz.question: During Special Play Time, if your child starts whining to get a certain toy, what is the best immediate response?
Quiz.explanation: Selective Ignoring removes the "reward" (attention) for whining, while immediate praise reinforces the return to calm.

QuizOption.optionText: Ask them calmly what toy they want.
Immediately give a Clear Command to stop whining.
Withdraw all attention (Selective Ignoring) until the whining stops.
Use a Labeled Praise to distract them.

title: Handling Chaos (Destruction)
shortDescription: Manage rough or destructive play using Descriptive Redirection and, if necessary, ending the session.

LessonSegment.bodyText:
If play turns destructive (throwing toys, roughhousing), we cannot use Commands in **Phase 1**.

Instead, we rely on **Descriptive Redirection** and Session End.

Use **Narrate** and **Echo** to describe the appropriate alternative.

**Scenario:** Child throws block hard.

ðŸ‘¤ **You:** "Wow, that was a hard throw! Let's see you put the block gently on the table, like this." (Model the gentle action).

If redirection fails or if the child is aggressive (hitting, breaking things), the session ends immediately.

**Action:** Calmly state, "**Special Play Time** is over now.

We will try again tomorrow." Do not argue.

This sets a firm boundary.

Quiz.question: If Descriptive Redirection fails and your child continues to throw blocks violently during Special Play Time, what is the correct next step?
Quiz.explanation: In the Connect phase, ending the session is the consequence that teaches that aggression removes access to positive playtime.

QuizOption.optionText: Give a Time-Out warning and escort them.
Calmly end the Special Play Time session immediately.
Continue to Narrate the throwing action.

title: You Are the Key
shortDescription: Discover why you, the parent, are the most powerful agent of change in your child's behavior.

LessonSegment.bodyText:
Parents often ask why they must change.

The reality is: You are the most influential person in your childâ€™s life.

Improving your skills is the fastest way to improve their behavior.

A therapist might see your child for one hour a week.

You are with them every day.

If only the therapist works with the child, behavior improves for that hour.

When you use these skills, behavior improves at home, at stores, and everywhere you go.

Take a moment to observe your child today.

Reflect on this: "It's amazing how much my calm reaction shapes how my child responds to challenges." Your positive attention shapes their self-esteem and safety.

Quiz.question: According to the Nora Model, who is the most important ingredient to a child's successful behavior change?
Quiz.explanation: The parent provides the consistent environment and reinforcement needed for lasting behavioral change.

title: Working Together
shortDescription: Focus on consistency and replacing old habits with new, structured positive interactions.

LessonSegment.bodyText:
You have likely read books or heard advice before.

Many strategies sound similar.

The difference with the Nora Model is not just what you learn, but how consistently and precisely you apply it in the right moments.

We are replacing negative interaction cycles with positive, predictable ones.

This helps you work together with your child.

By practicing **PEN** skills daily, they become natural habits that replace old commands and questions.

Choose one routine today (like getting dressed).

Consciously replace a Command ("Hurry up!") with a **Narrate** ("I see you're pulling on your socks!").

Watch how the dynamic changes.

Quiz.question: The main difference between the Nora Model and general parenting advice is:
Quiz.explanation: Structure and consistency turn good ideas into effective, life-changing habits.

QuizOption.optionText: It uses entirely new skills no one has heard of.
It focuses on precise, consistent application of skills in a structured sequence.
It only works with younger children.

title: Deep Dive - Praise (P)
shortDescription: Deep dive into Labeled Praise to specifically reinforce the behaviors you want to see more of.

LessonSegment.bodyText:
**Praise** is your most powerful tool for increasing good behavior.

But it must be Labeled **Praise**.

Unlabeled: "Good job!" (Vague).

Labeled: "Great job putting away the block!" (Specific).

Labeled **praise** tells the child exactly what action to repeat.

It also validates their effort.

Always try to link the **praise** to the specific behavior: "I love how careful you are using the red crayon."

Quiz.question: Labeled Praise is the main tool used to achieve what goal?
Quiz.explanation: Reinforcing a specific action makes it more likely to recur in the future.

QuizOption.optionText: To increase desired behaviors so they happen more often.
To distract the child from difficult emotions.
To teach the child new vocabulary.

title: Deep Dive - Echo (E)
shortDescription: Deep dive into Echoing to validate your child's feelings and build their language skills.

LessonSegment.bodyText:
**Echo** is repeating or slightly rephrasing what your child says.

ðŸ‘¶ **Child:** "The dinosaur is sleeping."
ðŸ‘¤ **You:** "The dinosaur is sleeping, I see!"
It acts as a verbal mirror.

Echoing is a "verbal hug." It builds language skills by modeling correct grammar without correcting the child.

Most importantly, it keeps the conversation moving without you having to ask Questions.

Quiz.question: What is the main benefit of using the "Echo" skill?
Quiz.explanation: Echoing validates the child and supports language development without pressure.

QuizOption.optionText: It allows the parent to give a hidden command.
It models correct language and makes the child feel heard.
It gives the parent time to plan the next activity.
It teaches the child to speak louder.

title: Deep Dive - Narrate (N)
shortDescription: Deep dive into Narrating to act as a non-judgmental sportscaster and sustain your child's focus.

LessonSegment.bodyText:
**Narrate** means describing your child's actions like a non-judgmental sports commentator.

**Example:** "You are pushing the car slowly across the road."
Imitation: If they crash a car, you crash yours and say, "I am crashing just like you!"

It teaches vocabulary and sustains the child's focus (attention).

It keeps you present and prevents you from slipping into "Don't" skills like commands or questions.

Quiz.question: When you "Narrate" your child's play, you are acting like a:
Quiz.explanation: You are observing and describing the action enthusiastically without interfering or directing.

title: Power Tips (Enthusiasm & Imitation)
shortDescription: Supercharge your skills with Enthusiasm and Imitation to show genuine interest and validation.

LessonSegment.bodyText:
Enthusiasm is the glue that makes **PEN** skills stick.

Use a warm tone and smiles.

It ensures your **praise** feels genuine and rewarding.

**Script:** "Oh my goodness, you look like you are having so much fun!"

Imitation is the ultimate form of flattery.

If they build a tower, you build one too.

It sends a non-verbal message: "Your ideas are great, and I love playing exactly how you want to play."

Quiz.question: What is the main purpose of the "Copy/Imitation" power tip?
Quiz.explanation: Copying the child shows you value their leadership and ideas.

QuizOption.optionText: To teach a better way to play.
To non-verbally validate the child's ideas and strengthen the bond.

title: The "Don't" Skill - Commands
shortDescription: Understand why Commands are strictly avoided during the Connect phase to maintain child-led play.

LessonSegment.bodyText:
A command ("Put that here") breaks the child's lead.

The goal of **Phase 1** is connection and child-led play.

Commands shift control back to you and risk a "negative interaction" if the child refuses.

Instead of commanding, use Description.

**Don't:** "Put the red block on top."

**Do:** "You are putting a blue block on the tower."
Let them lead now so they trust you enough to follow your lead later.

Quiz.question: Why must parents strictly avoid giving commands during Special Play Time?
Quiz.explanation: Commands disrupt the child-led dynamic essential for the Connect phase.

QuizOption.optionText: Because commands are reserved only for Discipline.
Because commands take the lead away from the child, risking a negative interaction.
Because the parent risks being ignored.

title: The "Don't" Skill - Questions
shortDescription: Learn why Questions distract from play and how to replace them with reflections.

LessonSegment.bodyText:
Questions ("What is that?") are often hidden commands or tests.

They pull the child out of imaginative play and force them to answer you.

This breaks their focus and "flow."

Your job is to be a mirror, not an interrogator.

ðŸ‘¶ **Child:** Feeds doll.

**Don't:** "What are you feeding her?"

**Do:** "You are holding the bottle to the baby's mouth."

Quiz.question: Asking "What are you building?" is a "Don't" skill because...
Quiz.explanation: Questions interrupt play and impose a demand for a response on the child.

QuizOption.optionText: It can take the lead away from the child and can feel like a test.

title: The "Don't" Skill - Criticism
shortDescription: Eliminate Criticism to stop the negative attention trap and build your child's self-esteem.

LessonSegment.bodyText:
Criticism includes "No," "Stop," "Don't," and pointing out mistakes.

**Example:** "That doesn't go there."
Criticism lowers self-esteem and breaks the safety of Special Time.

If you say "Stop whining!", you give attention to the whining.

This reinforces it! Instead, ignore minor misbehaviors and **praise** the good ones.

Teach them that positive behavior is the only way to get your attention.

Quiz.question: What is the main reason we avoid correcting mistakes (criticism) during Special Play Time?
Quiz.explanation: Correction undermines the unconditional acceptance required for building a secure connection.

QuizOption.optionText: Correcting is a form of criticism that lowers self-esteem and shifts the play from relationship-building to teaching.
The parent should not pay attention.
The parent doesn't know how to play.

title: Connect Mastery Check
shortDescription: Check your proficiency with PEN skills to ensure you are ready for the Discipline phase.

LessonSegment.bodyText:
Before starting **Discipline**, you need to master the **Connect** skills. 

**Why** ? Because positive attention must always outweigh negative consequences.

If you don't have a strong "bank account" of connection, **discipline** withdrawals will bankrupt the relationship.

Aim for this in a 5-minute session:
â€¢ 10 Labeled Praises
â€¢ 10 Echos
â€¢ 10 Narrates
â€¢ 3 or fewer Questions, Commands, or Criticisms.

Record yourself to check!

Quiz.question: Why is it crucial to achieve Connect mastery before moving to the Discipline Phase?
Quiz.explanation: A strong foundation of trust and positive attention makes compliance with limits much easier.

QuizOption.optionText: Behavior problems can't be solved otherwise.
Mastery ensures the relationship is strong enough to make discipline effective and accepted.

title: Introducing Discipline
shortDescription: Shift focus to compliance by introducing Clear Commands and Consistent Consequences.

LessonSegment.bodyText:
We shift from relationship-building to Compliance.

We are installing the roof on the house.

The goal is teaching your child to follow instructions.

However, we still use **PEN** skills during non-command times!

We introduce Clear Commands (specific instructions) and Consistent Consequences (**Time-Out**).

Without clear commands, consequences feel like random punishment.

Motto: Consistent follow-through is more important than the severity of the punishment.

Quiz.question: What is the primary focus of the Discipline Phase?
Quiz.explanation: Discipline is about creating a predictable structure where the child learns that listening is the best choice.

QuizOption.optionText: To make the child fear Time-Out.
To teach the child using questions.
To gain consistent compliance through clear structure and predictable follow-through.

title: Play-Based Commands
shortDescription: Start with low-stakes Play-Based Commands to build a habit of saying "yes."

LessonSegment.bodyText:
Start practicing with Play-Based Commands.

These are low-stakes instructions related to toys you are already using.

**Example:** "Please hand me the red block."

**Why** : It builds a habit of saying "Yes" without the pressure of chores.

Do this at the end of Special Time.

Spend 5-10 minutes giving 5-7 simple commands.

Use **PEN** skills in between commands to keep the mood happy.

If they refuse, use **Time-Out** (once you learn it).

Quiz.question: Why are play-based commands introduced first?
Quiz.explanation: Starting with easy commands ensures early success and builds a pattern of obedience.

QuizOption.optionText: Play-based commands are typically the easiest to follow, building initial confidence and compliance habits.
Cleanup is too important to fail.

title: Clean-Up Commands
shortDescription: Graduate to Clean-Up Commands using specific instructions and enthusiasm to motivate.

LessonSegment.bodyText:
Next, we practice Clean-Up Commands.

These are slightly harder.

**Rule:** Be specific.

Avoid: "Clean up this room."
Use: "Please put the red train in the bin."

Use **PEN** skills to keep momentum.

**Script:** "Please put the crayons in the box." (Child obeys). "Wow! You are the fastest cleaner-upper! Now put the paper away."
Enthusiasm makes work feel like play.

Quiz.question: When giving a clean-up command, which approach is best?
Quiz.explanation: Specific, bite-sized commands combined with praise prevent overwhelm and maintain motivation.

QuizOption.optionText: "Please put the two red cars in the bin," followed by PEN skills.

title: The 6 Rules of Clear Commands
shortDescription: Master the 6 rules of Clear Commands to ensure your instructions are fair and followable.

LessonSegment.bodyText:
A command is a test.

To be fair, the test must be clear.

The 6 Rules:
â€¢ Direct (Say it confidently).
â€¢ Positive (Say what to DO, not what not to do).
â€¢ Single-step (One action).
â€¢ Specific.
â€¢ Age-appropriate.
â€¢ Necessary (Don't over-command).

Poor: "Stop running and get ready." (Negative, multi-step).

Clear: "Please walk to the chair." (Positive, specific).

Poor: "Can you sit down?" (Question/Hidden Command).

Clear: "Sit down, please." (Direct).

Quiz.question: Why is it crucial to use Positive commands (stating what to do)?
Quiz.explanation: Telling a child exactly what action to take removes ambiguity and makes compliance easier.

QuizOption.optionText: Negative commands confuse the child about the expected behavior.

title: Positive Commands Practice
shortDescription: Practice phrasing commands positively to tell your child what to do, not what not to do.

LessonSegment.bodyText:
Focus on guiding the child toward the correct action.

**Don't Say:** "Don't interrupt."

**Say:** "Wait until I finish talking, please."

**Don't Say:** "Stop throwing."

**Say:** "Keep the blocks on the floor."

Avoid "Would you mind..." or "Let's try..."
These sound like choices.

Be polite but direct: "Sit down now, please."
Practice: Rewrite one negative command you used today into a positive one.

Quiz.question: A parent says, "Can you hurry up and put on your socks and shoes?" What are the two major mistakes?
Quiz.explanation: Phrasing it as a question implies choice, and multiple steps increase the chance of failure.

QuizOption.optionText: It is a hidden question ("Can you") and multi-step ("socks and shoes").

title: The 5-Second Wait
shortDescription: Learn the 5-Second Wait rule to give your child space to process and comply.

LessonSegment.bodyText:
After giving a **Clear Command**, you must wait 5 seconds.

**Do:** Remain silent and neutral.

**Don't:** Nag, repeat the command, or sigh.

This gives the child time to process and decide to obey.

**1.** **Clear Command**.
â€¢ **5-Second Wait**.
â€¢ Compliance.
â€¢ Immediate Labeled **Praise**.

If they obey, the cycle ends with **praise**.

If not, we move to warnings (coming soon).

Quiz.question: What must the parent do during the 5-second wait?
Quiz.explanation: Silence prevents nagging and clearly signals that the instruction has been given and a response is expected.

QuizOption.optionText: Remain silent and neutral, giving the child time to process.
Use a soft voice to encourage.

title: Praise for Compliance
shortDescription: Use immediate Labeled Praise to reinforce compliance and close the interaction positively.

LessonSegment.bodyText:
When your child obeys, you must instantly use Labeled **Praise**.

**Script:** "Excellent! That was wonderful how quickly you brought your shoes!"
This links the obedience to your positive attention.

Never follow compliance with "See? Was that so hard?" or a new command immediately.

End the interaction with the **Praise**.

This makes compliance feel rewarding, not just like a gateway to more work.

Quiz.question: Why is immediate Labeled Praise effective after compliance?
Quiz.explanation: Immediate reinforcement increases the likelihood that the compliant behavior will happen again.

QuizOption.optionText: It specifically reinforces the act of listening and following instructions.
It makes the child feel pretty.

title: Explanations
shortDescription: Understand the right timing for explanations to prevent arguing and delay.

LessonSegment.bodyText:
Explanations are good, but timing matters.

Option 1: Before. "We need to leave for school.

Please put on your shoes." (Best).

Option 2: After Compliance. "Thanks for putting on your shoes! Now we can get to the park on time."

Never explain during non-compliance (while waiting).

If you explain after the command but before they obey, you are distracting them and opening a negotiation.

**Rule:** Command -> Wait -> Action.

No talk in between.

Quiz.question: Why avoid explaining immediately after a command if the child hasn't obeyed yet?
Quiz.explanation: Talking during the wait period breaks the pressure to comply and teaches the child they can delay by arguing.

QuizOption.optionText: Explaining during non-compliance distracts from the command and encourages negotiation.
Explanations are for the other parent.

title: Running Commands
shortDescription: Apply your skills to Running Commands for essential daily routines like hygiene and safety.

LessonSegment.bodyText:
Now we practice Running Commands.

These are for real-life routines (hygiene, safety, bedtime).

**Example:** "Please go brush your teeth."
Only use these when you have the time and energy to follow through with a consequence if they refuse.

Don't overuse commands.

Only use them for important things.

If you command it, you must enforce it.

If you are too tired to enforce, don't give the command.

Quiz.question: Why are Running Commands considered the most realistic practice?
Quiz.explanation: These commands integrate the discipline structure into the necessary flow of daily family life.

QuizOption.optionText: They apply compliance skills to essential, everyday routines like hygiene and safety.

title: Selective Ignoring (Discipline Phase)
shortDescription: Use Selective Ignoring when non-compliance is accompanied by whining or arguing.

LessonSegment.bodyText:
If you give a command and the child whines or argues ("I don't want to!"), use **Selective Ignoring**.

**Action:** Neutral face, look away.

**Goal:** Ignore the whining, but not the command.

You are still waiting for compliance.

If they stop whining and obey, **praise** them: "Thank you for moving to the sink without fussing."
If they continue to refuse (non-compliance) even after ignoring, you will move to the **Time-Out** Warning (Next Lesson).

Quiz.question: When a child whines after a command, Selective Ignoring targets which behavior?
Quiz.explanation: You ignore the secondary behavior (whining) to avoid reinforcing it, while still holding the expectation for the command.

title: The Extinction Burst
shortDescription: Prepare for the Extinction Burst, where behavior gets worse before it improves.

LessonSegment.bodyText:
When you start ignoring whining, your child might scream louder.

This is the **Extinction Burst**.

They are testing: "Does mom really mean it? Maybe if I yell louder, she will break."

If you give in during the burst, you teach them to yell louder next time.

If you stay consistent and neutral, the behavior will drop off quickly.

Wait for silence, then **praise**.

Quiz.question: What is the Extinction Burst?
Quiz.explanation: The child ramps up the behavior to see if the old strategy (whining) will still work; consistency here is critical.

QuizOption.optionText: A temporary escalation of misbehavior just before it disappears.

title: Time-Out Introduction
shortDescription: Introduce Time-Out as a predictable consequence for non-compliance, not a punishment.

LessonSegment.bodyText:
**Time-Out** is a tool for non-compliance to a **Clear Command**.

Duration: 3 minutes + 5 seconds of quiet.

**Why** : Long enough to calm down, short enough to remember why they are there.

Pre-teach the rule: "If you don't listen to my directions, you will have a **Time-Out**."
Choose a boring, safe chair.

Have them use the bathroom before starting practice so they can't use that as an excuse.

Quiz.question: What is the exact duration of a Time-Out (ages 2-7)?
Quiz.explanation: This duration is evidence-based to be effective without causing the child to forget the original incident.

title: Time-Out Setup
shortDescription: Set up the Time-Out chair and learn to maintain emotional neutrality.

LessonSegment.bodyText:
The child must stay on the chair.

They can stand, sit, or wiggle, but must stay on it.

**Script:** "Stay on the chair until I say you can get off." You control the time, not them.

This is the hardest part.

You must be completely emotionless.

No scolding, no anger, no lecturing.

If you show anger, you are giving negative attention, which reinforces the bad behavior.

Quiz.question: What must the parent remain during the entire Time-Out?
Quiz.explanation: Neutrality removes the emotional payoff for the child, forcing them to focus on their own behavior.

title: Managing Emotions
shortDescription: Manage your own emotions and ignore all attempts to draw you in during Time-Out.

LessonSegment.bodyText:
While on the chair, ignore everything.
"I hate you!", "I have to pee!", "I promise to be good!"
Ignore it all.

These are attempts to draw you back in.

**Time-Out** teaches the child to self-soothe.

It also teaches you to regulate.

If you feel angry, breathe.

Tell yourself: "I am teaching them to calm down.

I am safe.

They are safe."

Quiz.question: If a child says "I have to go to the bathroom" during Time-Out, what do you do?
Quiz.explanation: Engaging with requests allows the child to escape the consequence; ignoring maintains the boundary.

title: Time-Out Step 1 - The Warning
shortDescription: Deliver the Time-Out Warning to give your child one final choice to comply.

LessonSegment.bodyText:
If they don't obey after 5 seconds, give the Warning.

**Script:** "You didn't [original command].

You need to [original command] or you will go to **Time-Out**."

This is the last verbal interaction.

Wait 5 more seconds.

If they obey, **praise** heavily.

If not, proceed to **Time-Out**.

This puts the choice in their hands.

Quiz.question: What is the primary purpose of the Time-Out Warning?
Quiz.explanation: The warning makes the consequence predictable and gives the child agency to avoid it.

QuizOption.optionText: To give the child one last chance to choose compliance.

title: Time-Out Step 2 - The Escort
shortDescription: Execute the immediate, calm escort to Time-Out if the warning is ignored.

LessonSegment.bodyText:
If they don't obey the warning, act immediately.

**Script:** "You didnâ€™t do what I told you to do so you have to sit on the **time-out** chair."
Escort them gently but firmly.

Do not argue.

If they resist, lift them gently from behind.

Place them on the chair.

Restart: If they get off, say: "You got off the chair before I said you could.

Stay on the chair." Restart the timer.

Quiz.question: If a child resists the escort, what is the technique?
Quiz.explanation: A calm, physical escort enforces the boundary without aggression or negotiation.

QuizOption.optionText: Lift gently from behind and escort calmly.

title: Time-Out Step 3 - Closing the Loop
shortDescription: Close the loop after Time-Out by re-issuing the command and praising compliance.

LessonSegment.bodyText:
After the 3 minutes + 5 seconds quiet, you return.

**Script:** "Are you ready to come back and [original command]?"
They must do the original task.

After they do the original task, say "Okay." Then give a new, simple command (e.g., "Hand me that toy").

When they do that, give Labeled **Praise**.

**Why** : This ensures the interaction ends on a positive note: Compliance = **Praise**.

Quiz.question: What must happen after Time-Out is finished?
Quiz.explanation: This sequence restores the relationship and reinforces that listening is the only way to get positive attention.

QuizOption.optionText: The child obeys the original command, then a second command, followed by praise.

title: Public Discipline
shortDescription: Adapt your discipline tools for public places with preparation and immediate consequences.

LessonSegment.bodyText:
In public, prepare your child.

Tell them the rules and the consequences before you enter the store.

Plan: Keep trips short.

Bring activities.

If they disobey, use a Standing **Time-Out** (e.g., by the cart or wall).

If they escalate or refuse, the consequence is Immediate Departure. "We are leaving now."

Quiz.question: What is the ultimate consequence for severe public misbehavior?
Quiz.explanation: Leaving demonstrates that misbehavior results in the loss of the privilege of being out.

title: Summary & Balance
shortDescription: Review the full model and focus on maintaining a high ratio of connection to discipline.

LessonSegment.bodyText:
You now have **Connect** (**PEN**) and **Discipline** (Commands/Consequences).

The key is Balance.

**Connect** must happen more often than **Discipline**.

Keep practicing Special Time daily.

Use commands only when necessary.

Catch them being good (Positive Opposites).

Consistency is your superpower.

Quiz.question: To maintain long-term success, what is the correct balance?
Quiz.explanation: A high ratio of positive interactions maintains the "emotional bank account" needed for discipline to work.

QuizOption.optionText: Connect skills used more often than Discipline skills.

title: Stress and Behavior
shortDescription: Recognize behavioral changes as signs of stress and respond with connection.

LessonSegment.bodyText:
When kids are stressed, they don't say "I'm worried." They change their behavior.

They might become aggressive, clingy, or regress (e.g., wetting the bed).

Notice these changes.

Instead of just correcting the bad behavior, recognize it as a signal: "Something is bothering them." They need extra connection and Special Time.

Quiz.question: Why do young children show stress through behavior?
Quiz.explanation: Behavior is the primary language of young children who cannot yet verbally articulate emotional distress.

QuizOption.optionText: They lack the words to name complex feelings.

title: Labeling Feelings
shortDescription: Teach emotional literacy by labeling feelings and using play to calm stress.

LessonSegment.bodyText:
Help them by naming feelings.

Model it yourself: "I am feeling sad right now." This validates their feelings and teaches them it is safe to talk.
When stress is high, increase Special Time. 5 minutes of undirected play helps them feel safe and loved, stabilizing their behavior.

Quiz.question: How does modeling feelings help the child?
Quiz.explanation: Parental modeling normalizes emotional expression, encouraging the child to identify and share their own emotions.

QuizOption.optionText: Teaches the child it is safe to talk about feelings.

title: Being a Role Model
shortDescription: Embrace your role as a model for handling anger and conflict constructively.

LessonSegment.bodyText:
Children watch everything.

If you yell when angry, they learn to yell.

If you remain calm, they learn to handle conflict calmly.

Use smiles and hugs to teach affection.

Solve problems rationally to teach conflict resolution.

You are their primary teacher of social skills.

Quiz.question: If a parent yells when angry, what does the child learn?
Quiz.explanation: Children mimic their parents' coping mechanisms, adopting the behaviors they see modeled in high-stress moments.

title: Managing Anger (60-Second Escape)
shortDescription: Use the 60-Second Escape to regulate your own anger before disciplining.

LessonSegment.bodyText:
If you feel angry, Stop.
â€¢ Recognize anger.
â€¢ Leave the room for 60 seconds.
â€¢ Distract yourself.
â€¢ Decide on a plan.
â€¢ Return calm.

Your anger fuels the fire.

A calm parent is in control.

Taking 60 seconds prevents you from doing something you regret and models self-regulation.

Quiz.question: What is the first step when you feel angry at your child?
Quiz.explanation: Stepping away breaks the emotional escalation and allows the parent to return with a rational, effective plan.

QuizOption.optionText: Leave for 60 seconds to calm down.

title: Advanced Boosters
shortDescription: Use advanced boosters like Distraction and Two Choices to prevent minor issues.

LessonSegment.bodyText:
For minor issues, ignore the bad behavior and enthusiastically draw attention to something else.

**Script:** "I have so much fun coloring!" (Redirects from throwing toys).
Give control back. "Do you want to walk or skip to the car?" Both options are acceptable to you, but the child feels like the boss.

Quiz.question: When redirecting, what must you ignore?
Quiz.explanation: Ignoring the negative behavior ensures it receives no reinforcement, while the new activity is highlighted as rewarding.

title: Formal Systems
shortDescription: Implement formal systems like If-Then plans and Sticker Charts for persistent issues.

LessonSegment.bodyText:
For older kids: "If you finish homework, Then you get tablet time."

**Rule:** Be consistent.

No work = No tablet.

For ages 5-8.

Focus on 1-2 specific behaviors.

Reward daily.

Note: **Praise** the effort, and don't criticize missed days.

Quiz.question: Why stick to the "If" condition in If-Then plans?
Quiz.explanation: Consistency creates a reliable structure where the child learns that their actions directly determine the outcome.

QuizOption.optionText: To teach that rewards must be earned and the structure is reliable.

title: Social Skills & Conclusion
shortDescription: See how your home practice transfers to better social skills with peers and teachers.

LessonSegment.bodyText:
Special Time teaches social skills.

Echoing models listening.

Imitation models cooperation.

Your child takes these skills to school and uses them with friends.

You have changed the dynamic.

Celebrate the progress, not perfection.

If you have a bad day, apologize, reset, and start again.

You are the expert now!

Quiz.question: How does Special Time help with peers?
Quiz.explanation: The relational skills experienced with the parent become the blueprint for how the child interacts with the world.

QuizOption.optionText: Models listening and cooperation skills that transfer to peer interactions.
